Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Pathways Project - Enhancing Climate Change Communication between Broadcast Meteorologists and Viewing Audiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This ISE award addresses the issue of disparity amongst media meteorologists in their perspective on climate change. Since the media has considerable impact on the public, this disparity of perspective is extraordinarily significant. One common factor in this issue is the education of these individuals at the undergraduate level. While there may be additional factors influencing these perspectives, this project will determine if the variation in coursework is responsible for the apparent disparity.

This group of researchers will interview media meteorologists, analyze the education provided at the 126 institutions that produce the meteorologists, and hold workshops that include media personnel, College faculty, and the public. From these efforts and data, the research team hopes to determine the impact that undergraduate education has on the media meteorologist?s perspectives.

This is a collaborative effort between 2 institutions, Bentley College and Plymouth State University. The focus of this pilot effort will be the New England area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A. Project Outcomes Report: Collaborative Research: Pathways Project – Enhancing Climate Change Communication between Broadcast Meteorologists and Their Viewing Audience

This two-year Pathways project addresses the high level of public skepticism about climate change science despite strong scientific consensus. In 2010, George Mason University /Yale University polls found that a full 30% of TV broadcast meteorologists denounce anthropogenic global warming (AGW) as a hoax or a scam. These polls also suggested that the general public trusts media statements over scientific facts, despite position statements acknowledging dominantly human responsibility for global warming in the past 50 years from nearly every U.S. professional society dealing with Earth sciences. Climate literacy in citizens and policy makers is essential for advancing responsible public policy on energy legislation, carbon emission reductions, and other climate change issues, and TV broadcast meteorologists have great potential for enhancing that literacy.

Intellectual Merit: This collaborative partnership between Bentley University and Plymouth State University examined ways to enhance climate change communication between broadcast meteorologists and their viewing audience, and sought effective ways to reduce skepticism among meteorologists, TV/radio broadcast meteorologists, and commercial daily weather forecast providers about AGW. The following hypotheses were tested: 1) A majority of U.S. meteorology degree programs fail to provide a sufficient number of courses specifically on climate change, covering salient aspects of the mechanisms for change; 2) Meteorology students, who typically earn STEM-rigorous B.Sc. degrees, graduate with an inadequate level of climate literacy; 3) Meteorology instructors, with Ph.D.s in meteorology, are unlikely to have educational backgrounds in paleoclimatology, or the climatic aspects of geology or oceanography, and so tend not to cover these topics in depth while teaching content on climate change; 4) Meteorology professionals who work on short time scales, on the order of 5-10 days, and develop mesoscale forecasts on local to regional spatial scales, often lack experience with pre-instrumental records of climate change and synoptic-global scale climate behaviors that would inform them about climate change; and 5) For meteorologists, differences in the type of quantitative training that they receive affects the credibility of their climate reports.

Outcomes include the following: 1) a quantitative survey of all 79 U.S. undergraduate programs offering B.Sc. degrees in meteorology or atmospheric science, which includes an Access database with over 6000 entries, a document that summarizes course requirements obtained from the latest course catalogs, and a summary of programs that include required or elective courses in climatology, climate change, or journalism; 2) a random sample, detailed, qualitative survey of first-year students and those nearing graduation selected from the B.Sc. meteorology degree programs in the U.S.; 3) a closely assessed qualitative survey of 22 TV/radio broadcast meteorologists in the New England and eastern New York areas based on phone interviews by a listening specialist to determine their basis for climate literacy, attitudes about AGW, and confidence in the scientific method; 4) two assessment-based workshops on climate science, one at the 39th Northeast Storm Conference attended over 100 undergraduate meteorology majors, and other at Bentley University attended by 10 TV broadcast meteorologists and 20 undergraduate meteorology students; 5) a database of 180 TV broadcast meteorologists in the New England and eastern New York area between 2012 and 2015 that includes their network and station affiliations, station...
